DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Caucus to Propose Change of Country's Name
Eds: SUBS 1st graf to fix grammar.
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity lawmakers proposed constitutional amendments Wednesday that include restoring the country's name to the prewar ``Republic of Poland,'' from the Communist-imposed ``People's Republic of Poland.'' Parliament convened Wednesday for a three-day session to consider sweeping economic legislation that was proposed earlier this month by the Solidarity-led government to transform the economy to a market system. The government hopes by the end of the session that parliament will pass wide-ranging laws that aim to reduce the current 900 percent inflation rate, make the zloty a convertible currency and reform the bloated state sector. In addition to the name change, the constitutional amendments would remove 19 articles, including one saying the Polish People's Republic is a socialist state and another that mandates the leading role of the Communist Party in state affairs. The prewar Republic of Poland was changed to the People's Republic of Poland in July 1944 when Soviet-backed Polish communists entered the country and proclaimed a Communist government in Poland. The package also calls for dropping the phrase that says the ``Polish People's Republic will strengthen friendship with the Soviet Union and other socialist countries'' as well as removing a clause which refers to the socialist system in the Polish economy. The amendments were presented first to the Solidarity deputies by caucus leader Bronislaw Geremek who appealed to the union-backed deputies to be present for the debate in parliament. Geremek said an amended Constitution would serve as a temporary one until a new Constitution could be drafted. The amendments must receive a two-thirds majority of the Sejm, as the lower house of parliament is called, to pass. The amendments also would create a provision for the formation of new political parties. As it is now worded, the Constitution allows only the Communist Party, the Democratic Party and the Peasants Party to operate legally. After the Solidarity-led opposition and Communist authorities agreed to partially free elections at talks this spring, union-backed candidates to parliament were forced to organize themselves as a club rather than a political party because of the wording in the Constitution.
